summary: This document is a chain of emails between US Attorney's Office (SDNY) personnel discussing how to handle document requests from Jeffrey Epstein's defense team following his death. The emails reference the termination of the criminal case (US v. Epstein, 19 Cr. 0490) and the routing of requests under Touhy regulations to the Civil Division.

keyFacts: Following Jeffrey Epstein's death, his defense team (Steptoe & Johnson LLP) submitted document requests to the US Attorney's Office, FBI, and MCC.
The US Attorney's Office (SDNY) internally discussed routing these requests to its Civil Division under the Department of Justice's Touhy regulations, as the criminal case was being terminated.
The government had submitted a proposed order of nolle prosequi for the criminal case US v. Epstein, 19 Cr. 0490, which would formally end the proceeding.
The emails indicate the US Attorney's Office position was that there was no pending "proceeding" related to Epstein's death and thus no right to discovery under criminal rules.
The correspondence reveals coordination issues within the DOJ on how to handle posthumous legal requests from a high-profile defendant's estate.
